problem.para: How many nonzero entries can an (n,n) diagonal matrix have?

answer.para: An (n,n)-diagonal matrix can have at most n entries which are not 0.

solution.para: A diagonal matrix is square shaped, and only entries in positions (i,i), 1\leq i\leq n, can be nonzero. There are precisely n such diagonal positions. Therefore such matrix can have at most n entries which are not 0.

answer.para: Such a matrix can have up to 3 nonzero entries

solution.para: Look at the columns of an upper triangular matrix of size (n,n). The first column can contain 1 nonzero entry. The second column can contain up to 2 nonzero entries. The third column can contain up to 3 nonzero entries, and so on until, finally, the n-th column can contain up to n nonzero entries.
